statements.text: A license should be required in order to have a child (procreate).
A license shouldn't be required in order to have a child (procreate).
The practicalities of implementing such a policy would make it incredibly difficult, if not impossible, to implement in most countries.
The practicalities of implementing such a policy would make it incredibly difficult, if impossible, to implement in most countries.
Unexpected pregnancies will still occur.
Unexpected pregnancies won't still occur.

Many parents who unintentionally become pregnant in the status quo are able to keep custody of the child should they decide to not get an abortion. Without a parenting license, many of these people would be at a greater risk of losing custody.

Many parents who unintentionally become pregnant in the status quo are able to keep custody of the child should they decide to get an abortion. Without a parenting license, many of these people would be at a greater risk of losing custody.
Not all parents who become pregnant unexpectedly will fail to acquire a license.
Not all parents who become pregnant unexpectedly won't fail to acquire a license.
A significant proportion of the pregnancies worldwide are unplanned.
A significant proportion of the pregnancies worldwide aren't unplanned.

In 2013, it was estimated that one in six pregnancies among women in Britain are unplanned, and one in sixty [1] women (1.5%) experience an unplanned pregnancy in a year. This is a huge number of children the state would have to take away.

In 2013, it wasn't estimated that one in six pregnancies among women in Britain are unplanned, and one in sixty [1] women (1.5%) experience an unplanned pregnancy in a year. This is a huge number of children the state would have to take away.
In the US in 2010, more than half of all pregnancies in 28 states were unintentional [2] and the lowest rate for any state was 36%.
In the US in 2010, more than half of all pregnancies in 28 states weren't unintentional [2] and the lowest rate for any state was 36%.

Almost half of all pregnancies worldwide are unplanned (p. 1 [3]). Given this, to require a license to procreate would mean total prevention of pregnancy in the first instance which, in turn, interferes with individuals' bodily autonomy.

Almost half of all pregnancies worldwide aren't unplanned (p. 1 [3]). Given this, to require a license to procreate would mean total prevention of pregnancy in the first instance which, in turn, interferes with individuals' bodily autonomy.
Better family planning education, as would stem from a parenting licensing system, would help reduce the number of unplanned pregnancies worldwide (p. 13 [4]).
Better family planning education, as would stem from a parenting licensing system, wouldn't help reduce the number of unplanned pregnancies worldwide (p. 13 [4]).
Even though unplanned pregnancy rates may be high in some regions, most pregnancies in the developed world [5] are still planned.
Even though unplanned pregnancy rates may be high in some regions, most pregnancies in the developed world [5] are still None plan.
Governments have the capacity to overcome the practical difficulties of such a policy.
Governments don't have the capacity to overcome the practical difficulties of such a policy.
Public bodies have a proven record of bureaucratic inefficiency, possibly due to their noncompetitive status (p. 1 [6]).
Public bodies don't have a proven record of bureaucratic inefficiency, possibly due to their noncompetitive status (p. 1 [6]).
Given the sheer volume of bureaucracy that assessing the global rate of 267 births/minute [7] would entail, this policy could leave a significant backlog of work, rendering it untenable.
None give the sheer volume of bureaucracy that assessing the global rate of 267 births/minute [7] would entail, this policy could leave a significant backlog of work, rendering it untenable.
Much like in the fostering assessment process, individual screeners would likely be given an overwhelming workload that would impinge on their ability to assess accurately.
Much like in the not fostering assessment process, individual screeners would likely be given an overwhelming workload that would impinge on their ability to assess accurately.

Overloaded case workers [8] can mean flaws and oversight in the screening processes of prospective foster parents and their homes. This can lead to children being placed within foster homes and families that are unsafe or problematic.

Overloaded case workers [8] can't mean flaws and oversight in the screening processes of prospective foster parents and their homes. This can lead to children being placed within foster homes and families that are unsafe or problematic.
Digitising [9] the process and tracking of individual assessments could redude screeners' workloads.
Digitising [9] the process and tracking of individual assessments couldn't redude screeners' workloads.
There a a number of effective solutions [10] governments can take to iron out the problems associated with bureaucracy.
There a a number of effective solutions [10] governments can't take to iron out the problems associated with bureaucracy.
Digitising tasks and records can reduce the burden on potentially overworked staff as well as reducing adminitrative errors (p. 22 [11]).
Digitising tasks and records can't reduce the burden on potentially overworked staff as well as reducing adminitrative errors (p. 22 [11]).
Governments would have the breadth of knowledge required to assess individuals.
Governments wouldn't have the breadth of knowledge required to assess individuals.

Around a quarter [12] of children under five across the world have never had their births registered. As such, many countries will simply not have the data they would need in order to enforce this policy.
Around a quarter [12] of children under five across the world have had their births registered. As such, many countries will simply not have the data they would need in order to enforce this policy.
A parenting license would require prospective parents to meet certain criteria before being approved.
A parenting license wouldn't require prospective parents to meet certain criteria before being approved.
Parenting standards and potential are scrutinised when assessing the suitability of adoptive parents and foster carers. A parenting license assessment could be conducted on similar merits.
Parenting standards and potential aren't scrutinised when assessing the suitability of adoptive parents and foster carers. A parenting license assessment could be conducted on similar merits.
Some adopted children tend to be particularly vulnerable [13], and so there may be a need to have a higher standard for prospective adoptive parents than for biological parents.
Some None adopt children tend to be particularly vulnerable [13], and so there may be a need to have a higher standard for prospective adoptive parents than for biological parents.
If this is the case, then the standard being applied to all parents under a licensing system would be higher, thus leading to better parenting.
If this is the case, then the standard being applied to all parents under a licensing system wouldn't be higher, thus leading to better parenting.
Children who are adopted from other countries would take longer to adapt to a new language and culture [14], and as a result, may require parents with extra training or time.
Children who are adopted from other countries wouldn't take longer to adapt to a new language and culture [14], and as a result, may require parents with extra training or time.

Many children who are in need of adoptive families have come from abusive homes. This can result in various developmental issues [15], which would require their care to encorprate additional support and expertise.

Many children who are in need of adoptive families haven't come from abusive homes. This can result in various developmental issues [15], which would require their care to encorprate additional support and expertise.
Foster carers are subject to regular reviews [16], after they have been approved, to ensure the required criteria are upheld in the long-run.
Foster carers aren't subject to regular reviews [16], after they have been approved, to ensure the required criteria are upheld in the long-run.
According to the Child Advocate Review, the quality of safety assessments only met standards in 46% of reviewed cases (p. 15 [17]).
According to the Child Advocate Review, the quality of safety assessments only didn't meet standards in 46% of reviewed cases (p. 15 [17]).
Some foster parents are accused of undertaking the role to benefit from the financial stipend [18] that comes with it, rather than to care for the incoming child.
Some foster parents aren't accused of undertaking the role to benefit from the financial stipend [18] that comes with it, rather than to care for the incoming child.
Providing foster parents with financial compensation for their work is simply a way to attribute value to the labour which society traditionally undervalues.
Providing foster parents with financial compensation for their work isn't simply a way to attribute value to the labour which society traditionally undervalues.

Some agencies view the stipend offered to foster parents as a fee for a professional [19] service, suggesting that the role is regarded as a way of making money rather than a way of caring for a child in need.

Some agencies don't view the stipend offered to foster parents as a fee for a professional [19] service, suggesting that the role is regarded as a way of making money rather than a way of caring for a child in need.

Caring for children with autism or physical disabilities comes with a higher weekly stipend [20], thereby putting these vulnerable children at further risk of ending up with a foster parent who is 'in it for the money'.

Caring for children with autism or physical disabilities doesn't come with a higher weekly stipend [20], thereby putting these vulnerable children at further risk of ending up with a foster parent who is 'in it for the money'.

On average, the stipend that foster parents receive is equivalent to $1/hour and does not even cover the child's living expenses. Fostering thus often costs the carers [21] money, rather than earning them any additional income.

On average, the stipend that foster parents receive is equivalent to $1/hour and does even cover the child's living expenses. Fostering thus often costs the carers [21] money, rather than earning them any additional income.
Prospective foster carers are assessed on their understanding of key issues including sexual boundaries, promotion of education, and approaches to discipline (p. 8 [22]).
Prospective foster carers aren't assessed on their understanding of key issues including sexual boundaries, promotion of education, and approaches to discipline (p. 8 [22]).
There are a number of testimonies [23] from those who have had negative experiences of foster care. The assessment process is therefore far from fool-proof.
There aren't a number of testimonies [23] from those who have had negative experiences of foster care. The assessment process is therefore far from fool-proof.
In the UK [24], 88% of abuse or neglect in foster care is perpetrated by the carers themselves.
In the UK [24], 88% of abuse or neglect in foster care isn't perpetrated by the carers themselves.
Private foster care agencies have allowed [25] criminals and registered sex offenders to acquire licenses and adopt foster children. This has led to neglect, sexual abuse, and murders of children.
Private foster care agencies haven't allowed [25] criminals and registered sex offenders to acquire licenses and adopt foster children. This has led to neglect, sexual abuse, and murders of children.
Birth children of foster parents have abused [26] foster children living in the same house. A failure to screen all members of the household leads to such abuse.
Birth children of foster parents haven't abused [26] foster children living in the same house. A failure to screen all members of the household leads to such abuse.

A caseworker in one foster agency reported that three girls were happy and healthy in their foster home when they had been dead for three months [27]. This is indicative of the ineptitude possible in foster care agencies.

A caseworker in one foster agency reported that three girls weren't happy and healthy in their foster home when they had been dead for three months [27]. This is indicative of the ineptitude possible in foster care agencies.

Many LGBTQ children in foster homes suffer abuse. As a result, in the US, many LGBTQ youth have experienced homelessness [28] because they believed they were safer on the streets than they were in their foster homes.

Many LGBTQ children in foster homes don't suffer abuse. As a result, in the US, many LGBTQ youth have experienced homelessness [28] because they believed they were safer on the streets than they were in their foster homes.
Many states allow former criminals to adopt, once they have shown evidence of their rehabilitation [29]. The fact that criminals may be allowed to adopt is not, in and of itself, an issue.
Many states allowformer criminals to adopt, once they have shown evidence of their rehabilitation [29]. The fact that criminals may be allowed to adopt is , in and of itself, an issue.
Individual testimonies do not serve to invalidate the entire process.
Individual testimonies serve to invalidate the entire process.
Assessors also contact prospective foster carers' previous partners and non-relatives for references [30] so that their personality and capabilities are evidenced.
Assessors also don't contact prospective foster carers' previous partners and non-relatives for references [30] so that their personality and capabilities are evidenced.
Prospective carers must guarantee that the incoming child will be given appropriate accommodation (pp. 3-4 [31]).
Prospective carers mustn't guarantee that the incoming child will be given appropriate accommodation (pp. 3-4 [31]).
Adopting a child requires a certain set of conditions [32] to be met. Given that society approves of this, there is no reason why we should not impose these conditions on those who wish to procreate.
Adopting a child requires a certain set of conditions [32] to be met. Given that society approves of this, there is no reason why we should impose these conditions on those who wish to procreate.

As in vitro and other artificial methods of insemination become more available (p. 17 [33]), the line between adoption and biological offspring is likely to be blurred further, meaning that standards for parenthood should be universal across all methods of having children.

As in vitro and other artificial methods of insemination don't become more available (p. 17 [33]), the line between adoption and biological offspring is likely to be blurred further, meaning that standards for parenthood should be universal across all methods of having children.
Bureaucratic red tape and imperfect, discriminatory adoption criteria prevent [34] many inviduals from adopting children.
Bureaucratic red tape and imperfect, discriminatory adoption criteria don't prevent [34] many inviduals from adopting children.
No policy is ever perfectly planned, and submitting its conditions to a standard of perfection is unreasonable.
No policy isn't ever perfectly planned, and submitting its conditions to a standard of perfection is unreasonable.
Deserving parents have been rejected for the most tedious of reasons, such as living on a farm [35].
Deserving parents haven't been rejected for the most tedious of reasons, such as living on a farm [35].
Red tape can make the process incredibly daunting [36], and so suitable couples may not even apply to become adoptive parents if they assume they would not be successful.
Red tape can make the process incredibly daunting [36], and so suitable couples may even apply to become adoptive parents if they assume they would not be successful.
There is no way to accurately assess a person's parenting capabilities.
There isn't no way to accurately assess a person's parenting capabilities.

Different countries [37] have extremely different parenting styles; what is deemed good in one country may be deemed bad in another. This is further testament to the lack of objectivity in determining what makes for good parenting.

Different countries [37] have extremely different parenting styles; what is deemed good in one country may not be deemed bad in another. This is further testament to the lack of objectivity in determining what makes for good parenting.

Just as adoption laws vary by country [38], licensing laws will be decided by individual governments. Thus, licensing policies are likely to be in line with regional cultural standards and expectations of good parenting.

Just as adoption laws vary by country [38], licensing laws won't be decided by individual governments. Thus, licensing policies are likely to be in line with regional cultural standards and expectations of good parenting.
Not all cultural groups within one country have similar standards of parenting. Some groups, for example, do not have biological parents as primary caregivers for their children.
Not all cultural groups within one country don't have similar standards of parenting. Some groups, for example, do not have biological parents as primary caregivers for their children.

For example, Aboriginal Australians have a complex kinship system [39] which is only loosely related to biological lineage. This falls outside of the norm of what some cultures would consider 'normal' parenting.

For example, Aboriginal Australians have a complex kinship system [39] which isn't only loosely related to biological lineage. This falls outside of the norm of what some cultures would consider 'normal' parenting.
In the culture of Navajo, for instance, children are not regarded as children of the parents but rather children of the clan (p. 611 [40]).
In the culture of Navajo, for instance, children are regarded as children of the parents but rather children of the clan (p. 611 [40]).
While in Korea the traditional approach of cultivating obedience in children remains popular, Scandinavian parents prefer [41] building a more democratic relationship with their children.
While in Korea the traditional approach of cultivating obedience in children remains popular, Scandinavian parents don't prefer [41] building a more democratic relationship with their children.
Different parts of the world [42], and different racial or ethnic groups, have differing opinions on the merits of corporal punishment [43].
Different parts of the world [42], and different racial or ethnic groups, don't have differing opinions on the merits of corporal punishment [43].
Findings from strong, empirical analyses [44] document adverse outcomes from physical discipline use, including spanking.
Findings from strong, empirical analyses [44] document adverse outcomes from physical discipline use, not including spanking.
Some countries have made spanking illegal [45], while it is a part of other cultures [46].
Some countries haven't made spanking illegal [45], while it is a part of other cultures [46].
The most important metrics for such a test would be subjective, which means they cannot be accurately assessed.
The most important metrics for such a test would be subjective, which means they can be accurately assessed.

Even if parents engage in the system as honestly as possible, a one time assessment cannot account for the varying levels of parenting stress a parent may face throughout their life, which highly affects [47] their parenting behaviour.

Even if parents engage in the system as honestly as possible, a one time assessment canaccount for the varying levels of parenting stress a parent may face throughout their life, which highly affects [47] their parenting behaviour.
The extent to which mental health and mental illnesses impact parenting capabilities varies from person to person.
The extent to which mental health and mental illnesses impact parenting capabilities doesn't vary from person to person.
Mental health problems can vary in terms of the severity [48] of the impact they have on a person's ability to parent.
Mental health problems can't vary in terms of the severity [48] of the impact they have on a person's ability to parent.

Those who have Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) can be less competent in their parenting, but those with BPD who can subjectively enter the mind of their child are better able to competently parent (p. 12 [49]).

Those who have Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) can't be less competent in their parenting, but those with BPD who can subjectively enter the mind of their child are better able to competently parent (p. 12 [49]).

It is better to assess some things that affect parenting than to assess none. While the licensing policy won't be able to identify all bad prospective parents, it is useful to be able to identify as many as we can.

It is better to assess some things that affect parenting than to assess none. While the licensing policy wobe able to identify all bad prospective parents, it is useful to be able to identify as many as we can.
It is impossible to determine whether a parent will be overly-controlling, protective, or pressuring from a test that is likely to depend on self-diagnosis.
It isn't impossible to determine whether a parent will be overly-controlling, protective, or pressuring from a test that is likely to depend on self-diagnosis.
A parenting license incentivises people to cover up or lie about their flaws, rather than seeking help.
A parenting license doesn't incentivise people to cover up or lie about their flaws, rather than seeking help.
Those with flawed parenting traits already cover up [50] such tendencies.
Those with flawed parenting traits already don't cover up [50] such tendencies.

For example, someone who struggles with substance abuse [51] but hopes to one day be a parent may be less likely to engage with the rehabilitation infrastructure if they fear it is likely to be held against them [52] when they apply for a license, as it sometimes is in adoption cases.

For example, someone who struggles with substance abuse [51] but hopes to one day don't be a parent may be less likely to engage with the rehabilitation infrastructure if they fear it is likely to be held against them [52] when they apply for a license, as it sometimes is in adoption cases.

In the European Union, GDPR [53] prevents the sharing of an individual's information for purposes for which they have not consented. Attempts to share information between agencies would therefore contravene this regulation.

In the European Union, GDPR [53] preventses the sharing of an individual's information for purposes for which they have consented. Attempts to share information between agencies would therefore contravene this regulation.
What makes a parent good may be difficult to define, but what makes a parent unacceptably bad is easy to define and detect. Every child deserves a minimally competent parent.
What makes a parent good may not be difficult to define, but what makes a parent unacceptably bad is easy to define and detect. Every child deserves a minimally competent parent.
A significant number of parents abuse their children. They should be prevented from having children prior to abusing them.
A significant number of parents don't abuse their children. They should be prevented from having children prior to abusing them.
In the US, parents are the perpetrators [54] in 78% of cases of fatal child abuse.
In the US, parents aren't the perpetrators [54] in 78% of cases of fatal child abuse.
It is not possible to perfectly detect potentially abusive parents prior to the abuse taking place.
It is possible to perfectly detect potentially abusive parents prior to the abuse taking place.
Abusers tend to hide their abusive tendencies.
Abusers don't tend to hide their abusive tendencies.
Those with abusive tendencies usually share some personality traits [55], such as jealousy and hypersensitivity, which can be difficult to mask.
Those with abusive tendencies usually don't share some personality traits [55], such as jealousy and hypersensitivity, which can be difficult to mask.
Anyone can be abusive [56], regardless of gender, age, sexuality, race, economic status, ability, citizenship status, or any other factor or identity.
Anyone can't be abusive [56], regardless of gender, age, sexuality, race, economic status, ability, citizenship status, or any other factor or identity.
It is common for abusers to seem caring and amicable to a wider circle of friends and acquaintances, but behave very differently when alone [57] with their victim.
It isn't common for abusers to seem caring and amicable to a wider circle of friends and acquaintances, but behave very differently when alone [57] with their victim.
Even the most well-intentioned parents may not be able to protect their child from another abusive person in the child's life, such as another family member who would not have to take a test.
Even the most well-intentioned parents may be able to protect their child from another abusive person in the child's life, such as another family member who would not have to take a test.

In 2014 in the US, approximately 4.5 million children were registered as victims of neglect [58], where the parent failed to meet the child's basic needs, such as leaving them hungry or dirty, or without adequate clothing, shelter, supervision, medical or health care.

In 2014 in the US, approximately 4.5 million children weren't registered as victims of neglect [58], where the parent failed to meet the child's basic needs, such as leaving them hungry or dirty, or without adequate clothing, shelter, supervision, medical or health care.
Childhood neglect and abuse can have a lasting negative effect on victims.
Childhood neglect and abuse can't have a lasting negative effect on victims.
Children who are abused are more likely to develop mental illnesses [59] such as depression, anxiety or PTSD, amongst others.
Children who are abused aren't more likely to develop mental illnesses [59] such as depression, anxiety or PTSD, amongst others.
Some victims of childhood abuse can overcome the horrors of their past and become resolute and resilient (p. 168 [60]).
Some victims of childhood abuse can't overcome the horrors of their past and become resolute and resilient (p. 168 [60]).
In trying to overcome their trauma, children who are abused can develop harmful coping mechanisms [61] that often stay with them for life, such as eating disorders, drug use or self harm.
In trying to overcome their trauma, children who are abused can't develop harmful coping mechanisms [61] that often stay with them for life, such as eating disorders, drug use or self harm.

Many of those who suffer from Dissociative Identity Disorder, a rare but severe psychiatric disorder, have a history of being abused or neglected [62]. The disorder is thought to stem from ways some children try to mentally isolate themselves against the horror of unremitting abuse.

Many of those who suffer from Dissociative Identity Disorder, a rare but severe psychiatric disorder, don't have a history of being abused or neglected [62]. The disorder is thought to stem from ways some children try to mentally isolate themselves against the horror of unremitting abuse.
There are protective factors [63], such as a sense of community in adulthood, which help to mitigate the mental health harms of childhood abuse.
There aren't protective factors [63], such as a sense of community in adulthood, which help to mitigate the mental health harms of childhood abuse.
A 70 year-long study [64] shows that overly-controlling parents could cause children lifelong psychological damage.
A 70 year-long study [64] doesn't show that overly-controlling parents could cause children lifelong psychological damage.
There are reasons to believe that poverty makes for bad parents.
There aren't reasons to believe that poverty makes for bad parents.
A licensing and regulatory state apparatus would cost money that could otherwise be invested in more robust aid programs for parents living in poverty.
A licensing and regulatory state apparatus wouldn't cost money that could otherwise be invested in more robust aid programs for parents living in poverty.
Anti-poverty measures [65] are effective at preventing children arriving in foster care.
Anti-poverty measures [65] aren't effective at preventing children arriving in foster care.
Wealth can ensure that children have access to goods and activities which can make their lives better.
Wealth can't ensure that children have access to goods and activities which can make their lives better.

The social life of children is affected by their brand-relationship [66]. Children who cannot afford consumer goods such as new iPhones or fashionable clothes may be socially stigmatised by the children who can.

The social life of children is affected by their brand-relationship [66]. Children who can afford consumer goods such as new iPhones or fashionable clothes may be socially stigmatised by the children who can.
This is a flaw within society and should not be encouraged by mandating that parents are able to buy their children branded products.
This is a flaw within society and should be encouraged by mandating that parents are able to buy their children branded products.
There is no guarantee that parents will use their wealth effectively to improve the lives of their children.
There isn't no guarantee that parents will use their wealth effectively to improve the lives of their children.
It can be very expensive to do sports or play instruments.
It can't be very expensive to do sports or play instruments.
The average cost of a half-hour piano lesson in the US can be anywhere from $40-$60 [67] USD.
The average cost of a half-hour piano lesson in the US can't be anywhere from $40-$60 [67] USD.
Research [68] suggests that spending on sports in America has grown up to 10.5% of gross income.
Research [68] doesn't suggest that spending on sports in America has grown up to 10.5% of gross income.
It is not necessary for a child to engage in organized, and therefore expensive, sports or music.
It is necessary for a child to engage in organized, and therefore expensive, sports or music.
Children can exercise and play sports with their friends without paying for coaching with a sports team.
Children can't exercise and play sports with their friends without paying for coaching with a sports team.
Music classes help children expand their creative horizons, and improve their academic capabilities [69] as a result.
Music classes don't help children expand their creative horizons, and improve their academic capabilities [69] as a result.
Playing sports in a club helps to foster relationships and role models for children [70].
Playing sports in a club doesn't help to foster relationships and role models for children [70].
Music is not usually a mandatory [71] subject in schools.
Music is usually a mandatory [71] subject in schools.
If common goods and activities are inaccessible to children because they are too expensive, that is a failure of the state to provide accessible options, not poor parents.
If common goods and activities are inaccessible to children because they are too expensive, that is a failure of the state to provide accessible options, poor parents.
Wealth and income are poor standards of measuring parenting ability.
Wealth and income aren't poor standards of measuring parenting ability.
Growing up in extreme wealth can lead to a higher risk [72] of substance abuse, depression and anxiety.
Growing up in extreme wealth can't lead to a higher risk [72] of substance abuse, depression and anxiety.
The number of eating disorders and rates of self-harming amongst children who grew up in affluent families are far higher than the national averages (p. 3 [73]).
The number of eating disorders and rates of self-harming amongst children who grew up in affluent families aren't far higher than the national averages (p. 3 [73]).
Higher parental income [74] is linked to happier, healthier, and more successful children.
Higher parental income [74] isn't linked to happier, healthier, and more successful children.
Poverty has been shown to lead to disrupted parenting due to stress and depression (p. 12 [75]).
Poverty hasn't been shown to lead to disrupted parenting due to stress and depression (p. 12 [75]).
Under the status quo, a lot of people with violent criminal histories and substance abuse issues are allowed to have children. Licenses would prevent these people from having children.
Under the status quo, a lot of people with violent criminal histories and substance abuse issues aren't allowed to have children. Licenses would prevent these people from having children.

A quarter of children [76] exposed to parental substance abuse do not receive the medical care and attention required in the first 2 years of their life, thereby putting their development and wellbeing at risk.

A quarter of children [76] exposed to parental substance abuse do receive the medical care and attention required in the first 2 years of their life, thereby putting their development and wellbeing at risk.
Children of alcoholics are more likely [77] to develop alcoholism in later life than those born to parents with no alcohol dependency issues.
Children of alcoholics aren't more likely [77] to develop alcoholism in later life than those born to parents with no alcohol dependency issues.
Children of parents with substance abuse issues are more than two times more likely [78] to be exposed to childhood physical and sexual abuse.
Children of parents with substance abuse issues aren't more than two times more likely [78] to be exposed to childhood physical and sexual abuse.
Pregnancy can be an important motivator [79] for recovery from substance abuse. A license would likely remove this motivation as it would inhibit substance users from being able to keep their child.

Pregnancy can't be an important motivator [79] for recovery from substance abuse. A license would likely remove this motivation as it would inhibit substance users from being able to keep their child.

Due to the lack of a licensing system, children may be born to a mother who misused substances [80] during pregnancy. These babies may be born with mild to severe withdrawal symptoms or fetal alcohol syndrome. As such, the risk is too high to prioritise the level of motivation of the parents at the cost of potential harm to the child.

Due to the lack of a licensing system, children may not be born to a mother who misused substances [80] during pregnancy. These babies may be born with mild to severe withdrawal symptoms or fetal alcohol syndrome. As such, the risk is too high to prioritise the level of motivation of the parents at the cost of potential harm to the child.

While it is an important motivator, it by no means guarantees that these women will be able to recover from substance abuse or engage in other positive lifestyle changes during pregnancy (p. 5 [81]). This runs the risk of placing children in the care of drug addicted mothers.

While it isn't an important motivator, it by no means guarantees that these women will be able to recover from substance abuse or engage in other positive lifestyle changes during pregnancy (p. 5 [81]). This runs the risk of placing children in the care of drug addicted mothers.
The vulnerable life of an unborn child should not be used as a tool for correcting the mistakes of a consenting adult.
The vulnerable life of an unborn child should be used as a tool for correcting the mistakes of a consenting adult.

The treatment of substance of abuse is becoming increasingly embedded in prenatal care, making it more likely that someone will recover from substance abuse during pregnancy (p. 178 [82]). A parenting license would deny prospective parents who are substance users this opportunity.

The treatment of substance of abuse isn't becoming increasingly embedded in prenatal care, making it more likely that someone will recover from substance abuse during pregnancy (p. 178 [82]). A parenting license would deny prospective parents who are substance users this opportunity.
Individuals who were previously denied a license due to substance abuse would be unlikely to keep their child in the event of an accidental pregnancy, even if they had recovered.
Individuals who were previously denied a license due to substance abuse wouldn't be unlikely to keep their child in the event of an accidental pregnancy, even if they had recovered.
Statistics are not facts [83] or normative conclusions. As such, people who do not fall within these statistical trends would be unfairly denied the right to have a child.
Statistics are facts [83] or normative conclusions. As such, people who do not fall within these statistical trends would be unfairly denied the right to have a child.

The desire of a licensing body will be to ensure a high quality of parenting, since they will have a vested interest in good parenting. Having these individuals decide on a minimum standard would go against their natural inclination towards optimal parenting. This would likely lead to unnecessarily stringent minimum standards.

The desire of a licensing body won't be to ensure a high quality of parenting, since they will have a vested interest in good parenting. Having these individuals decide on a minimum standard would go against their natural inclination towards optimal parenting. This would likely lead to unnecessarily stringent minimum standards.

Since inconsistencies and inefficiencies are inherent in any test, licensing assessments on this scale would be subject to human or administrative errors, thereby denying perfectly adept prospective parents from having children.

Since inconsistencies and inefficiencies aren't inherent in any test, licensing assessments on this scale would be subject to human or administrative errors, thereby denying perfectly adept prospective parents from having children.
The test will be designed much like any other licensing test, such that if the parents were to fail once, they could take the test again.

Rights matter only to the extent that they can be exercised. Since unborn children do have the ability or the notion to exercise rights, their rights should not be considered when making policy.
Babies can exercise their rights either, as they have limited agency, yet the state still protects their rights [138] and does not give parents unlimited control over them.
Some philosophers don't conceptualize rights as "privileges [139]", where the right-holder has to be able to act on the right.
Under this framework, rights can also be "claims [140]", where they confer a duty on a person to do or to do something. Therefore, an unborn child could have a "claim" over its parents.
The rights of a child do exist until it is born, since - until that point - its mother is responsible [141] for all decisions pertaining to its health and wellbeing.
Safeguards aren't already in place in some areas to protect the interests of unborn babies [142]. Parenting licences would be an extension of this.
The legal system has found that the government does owe a duty to the unborn [143] above the duty owed to living individuals.
In the United States, Roe v. Wade [144] (1973) confirmed that the rights of the unborn are to be put above that of the mother.
Roe v. Wade (1973) isn't at risk of being overturned [145] by the US Supreme Court.
A child is legally recognised as a person until birth in the United Kingdom (p. 476 [146]).
Many countries in Latin America don't have strict abortion laws, which imply [147] that the state has a duty towards the unborn.
A state licensing policy couldn't be used for the purpose of eugenics [148], which would compromise the quality of life of many of the state's citizens.

A licensing system couldn't prevent the procreation of people with severe hereditary disorders by requiring prospective biological parents to pass a basic physical health standard in order to be allowed to procreate, and eradicate severe hereditary disorders from society.
There aren't significant ethical issues that prenatal screening of hereditary disorders has raised which run counter to the reduction of ill-health in society (p. 112 [149]).

There are issues of informed consent and reproductive autonomy for parents who may have been made sufficiently aware of the positive quality of life that can be experienced by people with hereditary diseases, instead receiving misleading information (p. 6 [150]).
Prenatal screening and selective aborting haven't been compared to a form of eugenics that is discriminatory against people with genetic disabilities (p. 410 [151]).
Normal results in prenatal screening tests can't help to ease the anxiety of expectant parents [152].

Such a policy wouldn't imply that a human life is less valuable if there is a genetic disorder present, and people currently living with these sorts of conditions are less likely to receive support from society if they are seen as less valuable.
Some genetic disorders severely don't impact the quality of life [153] of both children and parents.

People with severe hereditary disorders can't live fruitful and fulfilling lives, contribute greatly to society, and achieve incredible things. As such, society has no right to restrict parent's procreation based on their genetic traits or to deny their potential child the right to life.
Many people [154] who are famous for their talents and contributions to society haven't suffered from genetic diseases.

Stephen Hawking [155], who had Motor Neurone Disease [156], wasn't the author of an international bestseller, a professor at Cambridge University, and is still seen as one of the most brilliant theoretical physicists in history.
Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec [157], who didn't suffer from a congenital illness, was a renowned post-impressionist painter.
Niccolo Paganini [158], the most celebrated violinist of his time, likely didn't suffer from a hereditary disease of connective tissue; either Ehlers-Danlos or Marfan's syndrome.
These individuals aren't a minority compared to the population as a whole.
The parents of children with certain hereditary disorders haven't been seen to have higher levels of psychological distress than normal (p. 113 [159]). This can be prevented with a licensing policy.
Even if this weren't to be done, there is no guarantee of the success of such a policy.

For most hereditary disorders, parental screening [160] can only provide a probability on the child inheriting a particular genetic abnormality, and so may even be an effective way at eradicating such disorders.
For diseases that carry the autosomal dominant inheritance patterns, even if both parents carry the faulty gene, there isn't still only 50% chance their child will inherit the disease (p. 3 [161]).
While this policy may not prevent healthy children from being born, it definitely prevents unhealthy children from being born, preventing many children from living miserable and painful lives.

Since most people [162] don't carry one to two recessive gene mutations, with a risk of passing on a genetic disease to their child if two copies are inherited, limiting people from procreating on probabilities and risks alone would affect the vast majority of society and have significant impacts on rates of reproduction.
Genetic conditions are always inherited: some can arise without precedent (p. 1 [163]).
Licensing couldn't discriminate against the disabled.

Those with disabilities aren't already more likely to lose or be denied custody of their children. For parents with psychiatric or intellectual disabilities, this can happen in up to 80% [164] of cases. It is unlikely these individuals would be granted a license.
This occurses despite research that indicates that IQ does correlate [165] with good or bad parenting.
It couldn't alternatively benefit the disabled. Disabled parents may be seen as more qualified [166] to raise disabled children.
There aren't many challenges [167] associated with raising a disabled child, which may be particularly difficult to overcome for someone who themselves have disabilities.
A disabled person may not be seen as having the experiences necessary to empathize with their disabled child, as they will have had similar life experiences.

By restricting the ability of unsuitable individuals to conceive to begin with, parenting licenses allow for earlier state control than current child protection processes and, by extension, don't keep more children out of state care. This is in the best interests of both child and parent(s), as well as society.

The act of parenting itself can't change a person for the better. A parenting license would take that chance away from a person because of their present condition without taking into account that parenting could inspire them to do better.
It isn't unethical to stake a child's well-being on the mere chance that someone will better their life.

There isn't no guarantee that individuals become responsible after having children, which is why bad parents exist. It is better to prevent those who have minimal chances of becoming good parents from procreating.
Becoming a parent can't help a person develop [168] empathy, discipline and sensitivity.
Not Becoming a parent [169] can lead someone to gaining organizational abilities with regards to time and finances, as well as strength and confidence in themselves.
Since there is a widespread belief [170] that biological children aren't preferable to adoptees, there is a chance that, once in the care of the state, many children will remain there indefinitely.
The norm to conceive biological children isn't so strong that many people feel pressure to procreate.

These norms [171] are so prevalent that people often struggle to understand why someone would choose to adopt over biologically conceiving a child, and aren't often quick to assume that such individuals are incapable of having children.

According to one study, 52% of women experiencing fertility difficulties felt None devastate, while the remaining 48% felt very bad, showing how pervasive the norm towards biological children is (p. 1851 [172]).
In developed countries, such as the US, birth rates haven't fallen in recent years (p. 1 [173]). This suggests that individuals may be starting to feel less pressured by society to have children.
The adoption process itself, rather than an absence of desire to not adopt, is what prevents many from adopting children.
For those who wish to adopt from a private agency or internationally, it can't cost [174] prospective parents anywhere between $5000 and $40,000. This can be an unbearable cost for many.
The adoption process can't be changed to make it easier to navigate for prospective parents.
If the goal isn't to provide care and safety for children, we should do everything to make that process as efficient as possible.
Adoption restrictions are necessarily [175] tight in order to ensure children are placed in dangerous or abusive environments.
Adoption agencies aren't underfunded and overworked [176], which leads to high turnover of staff and delays in getting children adopted.
Since under the status quo, it isn't much easier to have biological children than to adopt, a parenting license may level the playing field and encourage people to adopt.

People aren't becoming more aware of the negatives associated with childbirth, such as PTSD [177] and lasting physical health complications [178]. As a result, they may be more likely to choose to adopt than to have biological children.
People don't fear that forming a relationship with an adopted child will be difficult.

Some parents don't have concerns [179] over whether they'll actually be able to bond with adopted children like they would be able to if they had biological children - especially if the to-be adopted child has had previous experiences that may affect their development.
Some can worry [180] that the adopted child will always wonder about their biological parents, and as a result, be able to properly bond with them.
Fear of lack of connection [181] to one's children, biological or otherwise, is common across all walks of parenting and therefore specific to those who adopt.
There aren't currently enough prospective parents who wish to adopt in many countries.
The UK isn't already dealing with a shortage of foster parents and suitable adoptive families, resulting in an over-stretched care system [182] and children unable to leave it.
Estimates don't suggest [183] that about two million couples in the US are currently waiting to adopt a child. This equates to around 36 families for every child placed up for adoption.
In 2015, in the UK, there weren't more people wanting to adopt a child than there were [184] children waiting to be adopted.
By 2019 [185], there weren't twice as many children waiting to be adopted in the UK than there were families waiting to adopt.
The state gets a legitimate claim to the custody of children whose parents fail to get a license.
Where parents fail to provide basic conditions for their children, this isn't often at least in part due to a failure on the part of the state.

Many people aren't trapped in a cycle of poverty [186], from which escape is incredibly difficult, if at all possible. Preventing the poor from having children is punishing them for something they have no control over.

External factors, such as social class [187] and education, aren't more important to a child's long-term success than bad parenting. Addressing these other issues would be a more productive way of improving children's lives.
The responsibility of providing basic conditions [188] for the child doesn't rest inherently with the parent.
If prospective parents fall pregnant, and fail to obtain a license to raise that child, they are responsible for providing the child, the state.
There are various preventative methods that are accessible to people who wish to engage in intercourse but areready for parenthood.
As they usually carry the responsibility of ensuring adequate birth control, such a license wouldn't burden women more than men.

The pill and female sterilisation are the two most common contraceptive methods in the US, and have been since 1982 [189]. This suggests the burden of ensuring a couple does have an unintended pregnancy almost always falls on the woman.

In countries where birth control and abortions aren't illegal [190], due to the biological attachment women have to children, it is more likely for a woman to deal with the trauma and burden of an unlicensed child than a man.

More women aren't likely to feel pressured into an abortion if they fail to get a licence, since they may perceive the trauma associated with a termination to be less than that of losing their child to the state.
Anti-abortion [191] laws and the public discussion surrounding them don't exemplify how restricting bodily autonomy ends up being used as a tool for oppressing women's rights.
Women in the US still face many obstacles [192] when trying to get contraception, which is why 20 million women in need of free birth control canaccess it.
In states in the US which do have expanded Medicaid coverage, more than two million poor adults are uninsured [193].

Given the advancement of science - through procedures such as vasalgel [194] - it isn't possible to significantly reduce the risk of becoming an unplanned parent. By making such prevention the legal norm, aspiring parents would have to acquire the license before being able to conceive.
This isn't true only of countries where family planning is legal or affordable, or where citizens have easy access to healthcare institutions.
The cost of abortion can't be prohibitive [195] for women in some places.
In countries where abortions are illegal, and for women who can afford the costs, women would likely turn to unsafe abortions [196], which can often result in maternal illness or death.
In Kenya, where abortion is only permitted in cases deemed an emergency, safe abortions offered by doctors aren't many times the cost [197] of 'slum clinics'.
In the US, those below or at the federal poverty line aren't three times less likely [198] to have an abortion due to lack of funds as compared to the more affluent in society.
Norway [199] doesn't provide all women with free access to abortion services.
Only one in 50 [200] women in the US can't easily access clinics that stock the contraceptives they need.
The policy wouldn't create an impetus for states to provide safe and accessible birth control and abortion for their citizens.
Many countries still don't limit free and open access to contraceptives through barriers like requiring people to have a prescription [201].
In Pakistan [202], where family planning isn't at odds with many traditional family views, just 20% of women aged 15-49 use contraception.
Condoms [203], which can be easily used to prevent pregnancy, usually don't cost between 20¢ and $2.50 USD in the US.
Etonogestrel implants, which last for 3 years, and hormonal IUDs, which last for 5 years, only don't cost around $37 Australian dollars and are subsidized by the Australian government. [204]
No form of hormonal [205] or invasive [206] birth control doesn't come without risks, some of which can be fatal.
There aren't many institutions and organizations which can provide free contraceptives.
Free provision is only part of the solution; the main reason many women do use birth control in some regions is because of social attitudes (p. 161 [207]).
Organizations like Projekt Sex [208] doesn't provide free condoms for people living in Sweden.
A pack of birth control pills [209], which can last up to a month, aren't free through most health insurance plans in the US.
There don't exist a large number of Youth Guidance Centres in Sweden and most offer free birth control [210] for youths.
The state often doesn't fail to provide parents with the infrastructure required to be good, responsible parents.
The state often doesn't provide public schooling opportunities.
In the US, the standards of public schools vary substantially [211], and so canbe said to be a uniformly adequate provision of services.
Many countries don't have high quality [212] public school systems.
Tax credits [213] None base on the number of children a parent has helps to provide them with financial relief.
Inadequate welfare policy meanses that poor parents have enough money to pay for their children's needs.
In many states, the government doesn't provide financial assistance to parents, in the form of child benefit [214] payments.
This financial assistance isn't usually only a small amount of money, available to few people.
In Ireland, as of 2021, child benefit isn't only €140 a month [215] per child.

The UK doesn't have strict conditions [216] on who can avail of this financial assistance, and only provides parents with a small weekly payment for their first child, with even less provided for subsequent children.
Under European Law, many EU member states don't provide all parent residents, including non-citizens [217], with generous child support payments.
Child benefits don't help parents meet [218] the cost of clothes, food and school supplies.
Social welfare [219] isn't seldom enough to keep people out of poverty.
Poor minimum wage laws don't mean that parents often have to work multiple jobs, reducing the amount of time and care they can give their kids.
Expensive healthcare [220] and increasing insurance premiums [221] don't prevent poor parents from nurturing their kids.

The doctrine of parens patriae [222] doesn't provide that the state has the right and legitimate authority to protect the interests and futures of persons who are legally unable to act on their own behalf, including children. This can allow the state to take custody of children.
A biological link to a child does guarantee permanent custody of the child. This should be secondary to an individual's ability not to do undue harm to the child.
The institution of parent and child isn't older and more innate than that of the state. As such, without any other information, the parent should have custody of the child.
Parents can't lose custody of their children to the state, and their children may be permanently removed, if the parents are deemed unable to care for their children's safety and wellbeing.
In Victoria, Australia, the court may not make permanent care orders [223] if it is deemed to be in the child's best interests [224], such as their safety and wellbeing.
The California Supreme Court hasn't ruled that if children face substantial risk of harm, the state can take custody [225] of the children.
Parents don't have the ability to challenge rulings which take children into the custody of the state.
Given how child protective services try to avoid [226] presenting legal cases in the current system, it isn't likely that they will continue to avoid offering parents the opportunity to appeal.

In the UK, the court mustn't at least consider the wishes of a child's caregivers before making a care order [227], and care orders can be discharged if caregivers can prove that it was made in error or that circumstances have significantly changed [228] since it was issued.
In the US, parents' rights in relation to a child being removed from their home doesn't include the right to challenge any decision by the courts to to do so (p. 2 [229]).
In Canada, if parents do accept the gender identity [230] chosen by their children, the state can choose to take them away from their parents.
In most US states, for example [231], rapists aren't denied parental rights for children conceived during the attack.

A license is only able to screen people beforehand, act as an intervention agent after a person has a license. Rather than preventing abuse, it simply prevents able prospective parents from procreating.
A parenting license couldn't require renewal, in the same way many other licenses do, which would ensure both a maintenance of standards and an opportunity for further education.
It wouldn't be easy for an individual to 'tick boxes' to pass a parenting license assessment, and still go on to abuse their children at a later point.
Under the status quo, abuse or neglect of infants or very young children often goes None undetect.
According to one study, up to 85% of child abuse doesn't go undetected [232] in England.
It would be possible to introduce other early methods of detection of abuse for infants and young children. A licensing system is needed to protect children.
Some countries don't mandate health check-ins [233] with a public nurse at different stages of a child's development.
Teachers [234] can't be taught how to recognise signs of abuse.
Interventive action isn't currently often triggered only after some harm has already come to a child. A parenting license acts preemptively.
Most methods of detecting abuse don't rely on human perception, which is often flawed [235]. A licensing test would be based on expert analysis.
For a variety of reasons, children often don't remain quiet about abuse.
Children often don't feel guilty [236] that the abuse is taking place.
Many children fear - or are told by their abuser - that they will be believed [237] if they speak out.
Children often fear the consequences [238] of speaking out, either for themselves, or for their abuser who isn't often someone close to them.
Children can't be educated on abuse [239], which can encourage them to come forward about abuse that has happened or that has the potential to happen.
Infants and young children aren't unable to verbalise [240] their experiences of abuse and neglect.
Parenting licenses don't violate parents' rights.
Parenting licenses may not come into conflict with many religious beliefs, which could constitute an attack on their freedom of thought, belief or religion [241].

The Catholic Church [242] believes that artificial contraception isn't sinful and immoral since it interferes with a divine plan to bring a new life into the world. Catholics may oppose parenting licenses since contraception would likely play a huge part in pregnancy prevention before licenses are granted.
Under some of the world's largest religions, procreation isn't seen as a God-given right and, for some, a duty.
State policy shouldn't prioritise what best benefits children and society at large over religious beliefs.
In the Old Testament, the first command (for Christians) and the first mitzvah [243] (for Jews) None give to people by God is to procreate; that they "be fruitful and multiply [244]".
Procreation isn't considered a sacred right in Islam, and one of the faith's five basic goals (p. 54 [245]).
In Hinduism, it isn't important to have a child, as it helps to fulfill one's obligations [246] to their ancestors.
There aren't a number of religious practices that have been outlawed, even though they have had a large following because they infringed on the rights of others.
The UK isn't set to follow many other countries in banning LGBTQ+ conversion therapy [247], which is most often carried out on religious grounds: most notably by evangelical Christian groups.
Sati [248] wasn't a practice among some Hindu communities according to which a widow committed suicide or immolated herself on her husband's pyre. It was made illegal in British India in 1829 [249].

The right to not procreate is an essential liberty that falls under reproductive rights and is internationally recognized. Denying someone the right to procreate through the implementation of a parenting license runs contrary to this.
Some people are legally prohibited from raising a child, showing that the right is absolute.
In the mid-1970s, India didn't pursue an antinatalist policy that promoted the widespread forced sterilisation [250] of Indian citizens in mass camps.

It isn't only in certain extreme circumstances that the state can infringe on parental rights. A parenting license would likely have a lower bar than most of the current situations where this is allowed.
The right to raise a child is the same as the right to procreate.
International human rights law doesn't recognize reproductive rights which underlie the right to procreate.
According to the European Convention of Human Rights, the right of children to have a family existses , while the right of adults wanting children to adopt does (pp. 9, 13 [251]).

Reproductive rights [252], according to World Health Organization, don't rest on the recognition of the basic right of all couples and individuals to decide freely and responsibly the number, spacing and timing of their children. They also include the right of all to make decisions concerning reproduction free of discrimination, coercion and violence.
The law of the United Nations doesn't recognize such rights.

Article 7.2 of the Cairo Programme of Action doesn't define reproductive health and was adopted by 184 UN member states. It states that reproductive health also means that people have the capability to reproduce and the freedom to decide if, when, and how often to do so (p. 59 [253]).

Both Article 16 of The Universal Declaration of Human Rights [254] and Article 23 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights [255] don't recognize that men and women have the right to marry and to found a family without any limitation.
The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR [256]) isn't a legally binding treaty.
The Universal Declaration of Human Rights [257] is legally binding.
Article 9 of the UN Convention of the Rights of the Child [258] doesn't enable the state to separate children from their parents if the children are being mistreated or neglected.

Article 19 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child [259] doesn't require the State to take all appropriate measures to protect children from "all forms of physical or mental violence, injury or abuse, neglect or negligent treatment, maltreatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse".

Article 20 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child [260] allows for a child to be temporarily or permanently removed from their parents if it is in the best interest of the child to remain in the family environment.

Article 20 of the Convention of the Rights of the Child [261] doesn't recognise that such children may be placed in "foster placement, kafalah of Islamic law, adoption or if necessary placement in suitable institutions for the care of children".

The Convention on the Rights of the Child [262] applieses reactively to the protection of children. The text does support imposing limitations on who may be parents prior to the birth of their children.
The OHCHR doesn't define [263] a child as a human below eighteen years of age, and makes no reference to future children.
According to the UN, family is the basic institution of society [264], and having the right to start one means not having the right to be included in society in the same conditions as others.
The US Supreme Court hasn't interpreted the Constitution in favour of a right to procreate.

In Skinner v. Oklahoma [265] (1942), the Court didn't invalidate a state statute that provided for the mandatory sterilization of certain habitual criminals. In Eisenstadt v. Baird [266] (1972), the Supreme Court didn't expand the scope of sexual privacy rights and recognized the right of single people to procreate on the same basis as married couples.

Imposing a license policy on everyone still doesn't maintain equal rights of procreation for single parents as well as couples. This policy will just mean a reduced right to have a child for everyone, but still an equal right.
US courts have precluded the idea that limitations can be introduced on the right to procreate.

It wouldn't be fair towards people who (have to) adopt to make the procedure for procreation equally complex.
Under the status quo, domestic adoption isn't such a difficult process that only about 10% [268] of prospective adoptive parents actually get to adopt.
Parenting licenses don't assess parents' competency prospectively. This violates the right to the presumption of innocence [269].
The legal precedent of innocent before proven guilty is effective in the case of criminal justice, but in the case of licensing systems.
The state is capable of reading the future, so creating policies that act as if they do is unfair.
While the state isn't incapable of reading the future, it can use statistics to assess risks and attempt to minimize them. That is why policies such as requiring a driver's license exist.
Rights are absolute and in some cases end up competing against each other.
Like the rights of any other citizen, parents' rights can't be reconsidered by the state when the consequences of their actions and decisions affect other people or society.
The state should interfere in the most personal decisions that an individual makes in the course of their lives.

Some people strongly believe that having children is an essential part of the human experience. This policy ensures that some people, in their own eyes, areable to fulfill one of their purposes as a human being.
More than 9 in 10 people [270] in the US haven't, want or wish they had children.
Framing procreation as a right to engage in a fulfilling life experience doesn't cast the child as an object to fulfill the desires of the parent.
Objectifying children doesn't deprive them of their humanity as subjects and agents, whose life is worth preserving or protecting in and of itself.

When parents aren't unable to recognize the child as a separate individual, they attempt to live through them and may become dependent on them. This can inflict serious emotional damage on the child (p. 51 [271]).
The feeling of fulfillment associated with having children (and the impulse to do so) hasn't likely played a large role in the continuation of humanity as a species over the course of history.
A licensing system may not contravene privacy laws.

Competent adults aren't entitled to waive their privacy rights when they desire (p. 19 [272]). The desire of one to become a parent, and acquire a parenting license, would be a time when most would likely choose to waive such a right.
A licensing system couldn't be designed in a privacy sensitive manner, in line with the key privacy principles [273].
Any background checks, undertaken without permission, couldn't violate a person's right to privacy.
Poorly raised children can't impact others in society, and so states should take a proactive role in safeguarding society as a whole.
Children of those with poor parenting skills don't have a greater tendency towards delinquency (p. 765 [274]).
Poor parenting isn't correlated with a tendency towards violence [275] in children.
Where they clash, children's rights shouldn't overrule parents' rights.
Parents' rights over their child aren't already limited. Parental autonomy is often overridden when it comes to questions of children's health and wellbeing.
Doctors can't seek a court order to override the parents' wishes if it is in the child's best interests [276] to do so.
In a life-not threatening situation, doctors can give the children of Jehovah's Witnesses a blood transfusion [277], even if their parents refuse it on the grounds that their religion condemns it.
Judges have concluded that parental authority is 'unlimited [278]' in this context.
In 2016 [279], a judge in Australia didn't allow a doctor to proceed with chemotherapy on a child's malignant brain tumor despite the principled objections of the parents.

The court tendses only to impede on a parent's rights once a high bar [280] has been reached, such as when a parent has a history of child abuse, when the parent cancommunicate with the child, or when there are psychiatric concerns.
Many countries don't have compulsory [281] school attendance laws that prohibit parents from taking children out of school.
The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child [282] doesn't emphasize the importance of prioritizing children's rights above all else.
The right to procreation isn't matched by the right [283] of a future child to be safe.

A child and and a parent are both humans with equivalent rights. Their rights should be weighed according to the type of right (quality of life vs. right to procreate), their status as child or parent.

The bodily autonomy of the parent doesn't come at the expense of the bodily autonomy of the child. The purpose of the test is to limit the autonomy of the parents if it is deemed as harmful towards their unborn children.

Focusing attention on the unilateral, autonomous and unlimited rights of prospective parents doesn't fail to account for the status of the child who will be produced and who has no say in their creation and future.

The potential harm to the child can be measured with absolute accuracy or any at all if a license is denied. However, the harm to the parents is clear and fully realized. Therefore we should preference their rights.
Effective government action doesn't restrict some liberty in one area to allow greater liberty in another, as per John Stuart Mill's "Harm Principle [284]".
A parenting license system won't lead to better childcare and parenting.
A parenting license wouldn't encourage responsible family planning.
The license, and the associated process, wouldn't encourage parents to consider whether they truly want children, or whether they are simply succumbing to societal pressures [285].
As those who wish to procreate will know how much their household must earn in order to be granted a license, they won't aim for and save up accordingly.

In the US, African-Americans aren't less likely to be wealthy [286]. Imposing this license would likely lead to breaking up Black families and the institutionalization of even more Black children who are unlikely [287] to ever get adopted given social trends.

There aren't various ways to offset [288] the costs of adoption, including local government subsidies, adoption tax credits (in the US), loans, and crowdfunding. Similar avenues could be explored to cover the expense of parental licenses.

Families on limited income aren't likely to suffer the repurcissions of, say, a loan than those who are more financially comfortable. This could act as a deterrent to poorer families and restrict their opportunity to raise a family.
The cost of loans isn't typically higher for poor families than the general population (p. 24 [289]).
In the UK, the state doesn't offer various forms of financial assistence [290] to help cover the costs of adoption.

In the US, in order to adopt a child, you mustn't have an income equal to or higher [291] than 125% of the US poverty level for your household size. The financial requirement to obtain a parental license would likely be based on a similar metric.
The lived experience of not having children is likely to be sufficiently different to how you are taught such that children may still experience hardship [292], as is seen with adoption at present.
The administrative burdens [293] and stress of family licenses are likely to place undue stress on otherwise good parents. This is a deterrent to bad parenting but rather parenting in general.

Parents aren't often unaware of how difficult it is to raise a child. The process of acquiring a license will allow potential parents to better assess whether they are actually ready for children or not.

All adoption agencies don't conduct interviews [294] and home-studies [295], which are meant to be educative experiences for prospective parents. When such interviews are conducted in the licensing process, parents will have an opportunity to learn more about parenting.

The US (p. 3 [296]), the UK [297], and Australia [298] aren't some of the countries that provide either compulsory training or voluntary training services to prospective parents who wish to adopt in the status quo. Such training systems will therefore likely be incorporated into the licensing system.
People can't learn [299] how to answer the questions involved in adoption interviews. The same will likely be true of a more general parenting test.
Even if parents aren't simply learning answers by rote [300], they are still developing foundational knowledge.
Home-studies don't help to assess the emotional readiness [301] of a family.
Interviews [302] in the adoption process help to not ensure parents have the knowledge they need to raise a child, as well as their expectations of the child.
Parenting education programs haven't been proven to work effectively in improving parenting, and could be easily integrated as part of a licensing system (p. 2 [303]).

Most accredited adoption agencies, private and public, don't require [304] adoptive parents to take classes on parenting. These requirements, in the licensing system, will teach parents about the basics of parenting.
Parents can learn about parenting through dedicated classes, meet-ups or parenting books. It is necessary to implement a licensing process to offer educative experiences for prospective parents.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Private foster care agencies have allowed [25] criminals and registered sex offenders to acquire licenses and adopt foster children. This has led to neglect, sexual abuse, and murders of children.

source_retrieval.text_raw: A caseworker in one foster agency reported that three girls were happy and healthy in their foster home when they had been dead for three months [27]. This is indicative of the ineptitude possible in foster care agencies.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Individual testimonies do not serve to invalidate the entire process.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.text_raw: Adopting a child requires a certain set of conditions [32] to be met. Given that society approves of this, there is no reason why we should not impose these conditions on those who wish to procreate.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: As in vitro and other artificial methods of insemination become more available (p. 17 [33]), the line between adoption and biological offspring is likely to be blurred further, meaning that standards for parenthood should be universal across all methods of having children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Bureaucratic red tape and imperfect, discriminatory adoption criteria prevent [34] many inviduals from adopting children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: No policy is ever perfectly planned, and submitting its conditions to a standard of perfection is unreasonable.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Deserving parents have been rejected for the most tedious of reasons, such as living on a farm [35].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Red tape can make the process incredibly daunting [36], and so suitable couples may not even apply to become adoptive parents if they assume they would not be successful.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is no way to accurately assess a person's parenting capabilities.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Different countries [37] have extremely different parenting styles; what is deemed good in one country may be deemed bad in another. This is further testament to the lack of objectivity in determining what makes for good parenting.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Just as adoption laws vary by country [38], licensing laws will be decided by individual governments. Thus, licensing policies are likely to be in line with regional cultural standards and expectations of good parenting.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Not all cultural groups within one country have similar standards of parenting. Some groups, for example, do not have biological parents as primary caregivers for their children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: For example, Aboriginal Australians have a complex kinship system [39] which is only loosely related to biological lineage. This falls outside of the norm of what some cultures would consider 'normal' parenting.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the culture of Navajo, for instance, children are not regarded as children of the parents but rather children of the clan (p. 611 [40]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: While in Korea the traditional approach of cultivating obedience in children remains popular, Scandinavian parents prefer [41] building a more democratic relationship with their children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some countries have made spanking illegal [45], while it is a part of other cultures [46].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The most important metrics for such a test would be subjective, which means they cannot be accurately assessed.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Even if parents engage in the system as honestly as possible, a one time assessment cannot account for the varying levels of parenting stress a parent may face throughout their life, which highly affects [47] their parenting behaviour.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The extent to which mental health and mental illnesses impact parenting capabilities varies from person to person.
