source_retrieval.text_raw: Mental health problems can vary in terms of the severity [48] of the impact they have on a person's ability to parent.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Those who have Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) can be less competent in their parenting, but those with BPD who can subjectively enter the mind of their child are better able to competently parent (p. 12 [49]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is better to assess some things that affect parenting than to assess none. While the licensing policy won't be able to identify all bad prospective parents, it is useful to be able to identify as many as we can.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is impossible to determine whether a parent will be overly-controlling, protective, or pressuring from a test that is likely to depend on self-diagnosis.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A parenting license incentivises people to cover up or lie about their flaws, rather than seeking help.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Those with flawed parenting traits already cover up [50] such tendencies.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: For example, someone who struggles with substance abuse [51] but hopes to one day be a parent may be less likely to engage with the rehabilitation infrastructure if they fear it is likely to be held against them [52] when they apply for a license, as it sometimes is in adoption cases.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the European Union, GDPR [53] prevents the sharing of an individual's information for purposes for which they have not consented. Attempts to share information between agencies would therefore contravene this regulation.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: What makes a parent good may be difficult to define, but what makes a parent unacceptably bad is easy to define and detect. Every child deserves a minimally competent parent.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A significant number of parents abuse their children. They should be prevented from having children prior to abusing them.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the US, parents are the perpetrators [54] in 78% of cases of fatal child abuse.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is not possible to perfectly detect potentially abusive parents prior to the abuse taking place.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Abusers tend to hide their abusive tendencies.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Those with abusive tendencies usually share some personality traits [55], such as jealousy and hypersensitivity, which can be difficult to mask.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Anyone can be abusive [56], regardless of gender, age, sexuality, race, economic status, ability, citizenship status, or any other factor or identity.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.text_raw: Even the most well-intentioned parents may not be able to protect their child from another abusive person in the child's life, such as another family member who would not have to take a test.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 2014 in the US, approximately 4.5 million children were registered as victims of neglect [58], where the parent failed to meet the child's basic needs, such as leaving them hungry or dirty, or without adequate clothing, shelter, supervision, medical or health care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Childhood neglect and abuse can have a lasting negative effect on victims.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.text_raw: In trying to overcome their trauma, children who are abused can develop harmful coping mechanisms [61] that often stay with them for life, such as eating disorders, drug use or self harm.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are protective factors [63], such as a sense of community in adulthood, which help to mitigate the mental health harms of childhood abuse.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A 70 year-long study [64] shows that overly-controlling parents could cause children lifelong psychological damage.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are reasons to believe that poverty makes for bad parents.

source_retrieval.text_raw: A licensing and regulatory state apparatus would cost money that could otherwise be invested in more robust aid programs for parents living in poverty.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Anti-poverty measures [65] are effective at preventing children arriving in foster care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Wealth can ensure that children have access to goods and activities which can make their lives better.

source_retrieval.text_raw: There is no guarantee that parents will use their wealth effectively to improve the lives of their children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is not necessary for a child to engage in organized, and therefore expensive, sports or music.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If common goods and activities are inaccessible to children because they are too expensive, that is a failure of the state to provide accessible options, not poor parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Wealth and income are poor standards of measuring parenting ability.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Growing up in extreme wealth can lead to a higher risk [72] of substance abuse, depression and anxiety.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The number of eating disorders and rates of self-harming amongst children who grew up in affluent families are far higher than the national averages (p. 3 [73]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Higher parental income [74] is linked to happier, healthier, and more successful children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Poverty has been shown to lead to disrupted parenting due to stress and depression (p. 12 [75]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Under the status quo, a lot of people with violent criminal histories and substance abuse issues are allowed to have children. Licenses would prevent these people from having children.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Pregnancy can be an important motivator [79] for recovery from substance abuse. A license would likely remove this motivation as it would inhibit substance users from being able to keep their child.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The vulnerable life of an unborn child should not be used as a tool for correcting the mistakes of a consenting adult.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Individuals who were previously denied a license due to substance abuse would be unlikely to keep their child in the event of an accidental pregnancy, even if they had recovered.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Statistics are not facts [83] or normative conclusions. As such, people who do not fall within these statistical trends would be unfairly denied the right to have a child.

source_retrieval.text_raw: The desire of a licensing body will be to ensure a high quality of parenting, since they will have a vested interest in good parenting. source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Since inconsistencies and inefficiencies are inherent in any test, licensing assessments on this scale would be subject to human or administrative errors, thereby denying perfectly adept prospective parents from having children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The test will be designed much like any other licensing test, such that if the parents were to fail once, they could take the test again.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is unlikely that deserving parents will fail the test multiple times, as they will be better prepared for each successive retake.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In such an instance, the child would still be removed from the parents' custody till such time that they passed the test. This separation, even if temporary, would be harmful to the parents and to the child.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is no guarantee that everyone will be able to pass the test, especially if financial requirements are part of the licensing process. source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Problems such as inconsistencies or cheating with the parent licensing test can be dealt with and the margin of error can be minimized. As long as the overall system can properly function, minor incidents should not justify opposing the policy.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Inconsistencies and inefficiencies are also inherent within the judicial system [85]. A state establishing a judicial system as a flawed structure that adds order to society is still better than having no legal structure at all.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Effectively utilizing error management can significantly limit human and administrative errors (p. 770 [86]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This inconsistency already exists in the status quo. Adding a test and licensing system adds some level of order to the inconsistencies that exist, even if the test is not perfect.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the past, administrative and human errors have impeded people from voting [87], mis-scored students' SATs [88] and led to a wrongfully amputated leg [89]. Even when the stakes are high, human error is always a possibility.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many of these errors, where possible, are quickly and seamlessly rectified or compensated.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Fewer people would have children under this policy, resulting in a population decrease that would be of practical benefit to many countries.

source_retrieval.text_raw: The promotion of family planning through education would be a preferable policy as it maximizes choice for the individuals involved.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Significant sexual education [93] has been associated with lower reports of teenage pregnancy.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is preferable for the state to pursue a policy which affords people choice and autonomy to one which dictates to them, as people [94] do not like being told what to do, and may be more likely to act in defiance of the policy as a result.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Some people may not be affected by family planning education [95], and continue to have children, therefore minimizing the effect education would have on overpopulation.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting licenses would be an immediate solution, which would not require time for attitude and behavioral change. For urgent issues related to overpopulation, like climate change [97], this makes parenting licenses the best option.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Many countries [106], including Japan, Germany, and Russia, have declining populations. Further limiting the population would exacerbate the problems of labor shortages [107] and overburdened pensions that underpopulation already causes.

source_retrieval.text_raw: A parenting license will discourage people from having children. The birthrates in many developed countries are already far below the replacement fertility rate [109].

source_retrieval.text_raw: The policy will lead to stigma against couples who fail to gain a parenting license, which may deter people from applying for a license to begin with.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.text_raw: There are an estimated 13 million children [116] in China that were born without state permission. This indicates the difficulty of ensuring compliance with a policy that regulates procreation.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Barriers to activities that affect the functioning of society are already enforced, such as practicing law [120] or medicine [121]. Licensing parents to raise healthy and productive future members of society is not vastly different.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting should not be seen as analogous to professions like medicine and law.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.text_raw: Medicine [122] and law [123] both require years of training and learning, whereas parenting typically comes naturally to people.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting styles and quality can vary wildly. A licensing system will at the very least teach the basics of raising a child, guaranteeing a minimum standard of parenting and care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting does not come naturally [124] to everyone. For example, adults who were victims of child abuse may struggle.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Most young mothers [125] believe parenting comes naturally to them.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Young mothers may not be aware of how much they do not know. Older mothers are less confident [126] that their ability comes naturally.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting is an instinct [127] that has evolved in many animals, humans included, to ensure the survival of their species.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Failure as a parent, along with failure as a doctor or a lawyer, has severe consequences.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Historically, instances of restricting unintended procreation among specific groups [128] in society have been achieved by forced use of contraceptive methods, including forced sterilisation [129].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Forced sterilization can constitute genocide [130] and discrimination, and has been used across the world to oppress [131] minority groups.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Without totalitarian violence, those with the means might move to other countries with less stringent requirements in order to be able to have children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: For parents, leaving the country would likely mean leaving any stable job. Their potential children will end up even worse off than before the licensing law.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In most cases, parents have the majority of a pregnancy to plan the birth of their child. There is no reason why those in licensed states could not simply cross a border before giving birth in order to circumvent licensing requirements.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Governments are obligated to improve and maintain citizens' quality of life. Introducing parenting licenses would help facilitate this.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The responsibility to maximise quality of life lies with the individual, not the state.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is the duty of the benign state only to reflect [132] accurately the values and choices of the governed, as decided through elections and other polling initiatives. Unless quality of life has been stipulated as one such value - via an election or ballot initiative, for example - it is not automatically the responsibility of the state.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The negative effects of bad parenting, including bad behaviour [133] and increased likelihood of substance abuse [134], affect society at large. It is therefore the duty of the state to minimise such harm.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: While responsibility initially rests with the individuals, if the individuals agree to a state policy to hold themselves accountable, the state becomes responsible to provide that accountability.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: People have different views of what makes for a good life, so state intervention should only intervene in ways that maximize their options for their lives, leaving exclusive control [135] over an individual's choices to the individual themselves.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A parenting license would ultimately limit people's choices and confine them to the state's expectations.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state is justified [136] in limiting what people can do if it helps to minimize harm in society.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The government of a state is ultimately made up of a small, and often privileged, group of individuals who have a limited conception [137] of what constitutes a good life.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The biggest beneficiaries of a parenting licensing policy would be unborn children, to which the state owe a moral - and to some extent legal - duty.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state must take into consideration the future implications of a policy when implementing it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Unconceived future children, either as specific intended children or as future generations, have no current ontological status and thus no current interests or rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: As long as a currently unconceived person can be portrayed as an actual victim of harm once they exist, they have a right to not be harmed at this point in time.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Rights matter only to the extent that they can be exercised. Since unborn children do not have the ability or the notion to exercise rights, their rights should not be considered when making policy.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Babies cannot exercise their rights either, as they have limited agency, yet the state still protects their rights [138] and does not give parents unlimited control over them.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some philosophers conceptualize rights as "privileges [139]", where the right-holder has to be able to act on the right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Under this framework, rights can also be "claims [140]", where they confer a duty on a person to do or not to do something. Therefore, an unborn child could have a "claim" over its parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The rights of a child do not exist until it is born, since - until that point - its mother is responsible [141] for all decisions pertaining to its health and wellbeing.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Safeguards are already in place in some areas to protect the interests of unborn babies [142]. Parenting licences would be an extension of this.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The legal system has found that the government does not owe a duty to the unborn [143] above the duty owed to living individuals.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the United States, Roe v. Wade [144] (1973) confirmed that the rights of the unborn are not to be put above that of the mother.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Roe v. Wade (1973) is at risk of being overturned [145] by the US Supreme Court.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A child is not legally recognised as a person until birth in the United Kingdom (p. 476 [146]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many countries in Latin America have strict abortion laws, which imply [147] that the state has a duty towards the unborn.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A state licensing policy could be used for the purpose of eugenics [148], which would compromise the quality of life of many of the state's citizens.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A licensing system could prevent the procreation of people with severe hereditary disorders by requiring prospective biological parents to pass a basic physical health standard in order to be allowed to procreate, and eradicate severe hereditary disorders from society.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are significant ethical issues that prenatal screening of hereditary disorders has raised which run counter to the reduction of ill-health in society (p. 112 [149]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are issues of informed consent and reproductive autonomy for parents who may not have been made sufficiently aware of the positive quality of life that can be experienced by people with hereditary diseases, instead receiving misleading information (p. 6 [150]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Prenatal screening and selective aborting have been compared to a form of eugenics that is discriminatory against people with genetic disabilities (p. 410 [151]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Normal results in prenatal screening tests can help to ease the anxiety of expectant parents [152].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Such a policy would imply that a human life is less valuable if there is a genetic disorder present, and people currently living with these sorts of conditions are less likely to receive support from society if they are seen as less valuable.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some genetic disorders severely impact the quality of life [153] of both children and parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: People with severe hereditary disorders can live fruitful and fulfilling lives, contribute greatly to society, and achieve incredible things. As such, society has no right to restrict parent's procreation based on their genetic traits or to deny their potential child the right to life.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many people [154] who are famous for their talents and contributions to society have suffered from genetic diseases.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Stephen Hawking [155], who had Motor Neurone Disease [156], was the author of an international bestseller, a professor at Cambridge University, and is still seen as one of the most brilliant theoretical physicists in history.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec [157], who suffered from a congenital illness, was a renowned post-impressionist painter.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Niccolo Paganini [158], the most celebrated violinist of his time, likely suffered from a hereditary disease of connective tissue; either Ehlers-Danlos or Marfan's syndrome.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: These individuals are a minority compared to the population as a whole.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The parents of children with certain hereditary disorders have been seen to have higher levels of psychological distress than normal (p. 113 [159]). This can be prevented with a licensing policy.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Even if this were to be done, there is no guarantee of the success of such a policy.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: For most hereditary disorders, parental screening [160] can only provide a probability on the child inheriting a particular genetic abnormality, and so may not even be an effective way at eradicating such disorders.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: For diseases that carry the autosomal dominant inheritance patterns, even if both parents carry the faulty gene, there is still only 50% chance their child will inherit the disease (p. 3 [161]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: While this policy may prevent healthy children from being born, it definitely prevents unhealthy children from being born, preventing many children from living miserable and painful lives.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Since most people [162] carry one to two recessive gene mutations, with a risk of passing on a genetic disease to their child if two copies are inherited, limiting people from procreating on probabilities and risks alone would affect the vast majority of society and have significant impacts on rates of reproduction.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Genetic conditions are not always inherited: some can arise without precedent (p. 1 [163]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Licensing could discriminate against the disabled.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Those with disabilities are already more likely to lose or be denied custody of their children. For parents with psychiatric or intellectual disabilities, this can happen in up to 80% [164] of cases. It is unlikely these individuals would be granted a license.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This occurs despite research that indicates that IQ does not correlate [165] with good or bad parenting.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It could alternatively benefit the disabled. Disabled parents may be seen as more qualified [166] to raise disabled children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are many challenges [167] associated with raising a disabled child, which may be particularly difficult to overcome for someone who themselves have disabilities.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A disabled person may be seen as having the experiences necessary to empathize with their disabled child, as they will have had similar life experiences.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: By restricting the ability of unsuitable individuals to conceive to begin with, parenting licenses allow for earlier state control than current child protection processes and, by extension, keep more children out of state care. This is in the best interests of both child and parent(s), as well as society.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The act of parenting itself can change a person for the better. A parenting license would take that chance away from a person because of their present condition without taking into account that parenting could inspire them to do better.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is unethical to stake a child's well-being on the mere chance that someone will better their life.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is no guarantee that individuals become responsible after having children, which is why bad parents exist. It is better to prevent those who have minimal chances of becoming good parents from procreating.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Becoming a parent can help a person develop [168] empathy, discipline and sensitivity.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Becoming a parent [169] can lead someone to gaining organizational abilities with regards to time and finances, as well as strength and confidence in themselves.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Since there is a widespread belief [170] that biological children are preferable to adoptees, there is a chance that, once in the care of the state, many children will remain there indefinitely.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The norm to conceive biological children is so strong that many people feel pressure to procreate.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: These norms [171] are so prevalent that people often struggle to understand why someone would choose to adopt over biologically conceiving a child, and are often quick to assume that such individuals are incapable of having children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: According to one study, 52% of women experiencing fertility difficulties felt devastated, while the remaining 48% felt very bad, showing how pervasive the norm towards biological children is (p. 1851 [172]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In developed countries, such as the US, birth rates have fallen in recent years (p. 1 [173]). This suggests that individuals may be starting to feel less pressured by society to have children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The adoption process itself, rather than an absence of desire to adopt, is what prevents many from adopting children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: For those who wish to adopt from a private agency or internationally, it can cost [174] prospective parents anywhere between $5000 and $40,000. This can be an unbearable cost for many.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The adoption process can be changed to make it easier to navigate for prospective parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If the goal is to provide care and safety for children, we should do everything to make that process as efficient as possible.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Adoption restrictions are necessarily [175] tight in order to ensure children are not placed in dangerous or abusive environments.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Adoption agencies are underfunded and overworked [176], which leads to high turnover of staff and delays in getting children adopted.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Since under the status quo, it is much easier to have biological children than to adopt, a parenting license may level the playing field and encourage people to adopt.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: People are becoming more aware of the negatives associated with childbirth, such as PTSD [177] and lasting physical health complications [178]. As a result, they may be more likely to choose to adopt than to have biological children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: People fear that forming a relationship with an adopted child will be difficult.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some parents have concerns [179] over whether they'll actually be able to bond with adopted children like they would be able to if they had biological children - especially if the to-be adopted child has had previous experiences that may affect their development.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some can worry [180] that the adopted child will always wonder about their biological parents, and as a result, never be able to properly bond with them.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Fear of lack of connection [181] to one's children, biological or otherwise, is common across all walks of parenting and therefore not specific to those who adopt.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are currently enough prospective parents who wish to adopt in many countries.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The UK is already dealing with a shortage of foster parents and suitable adoptive families, resulting in an over-stretched care system [182] and children unable to leave it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Estimates suggest [183] that about two million couples in the US are currently waiting to adopt a child. This equates to around 36 families for every child placed up for adoption.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 2015, in the UK, there were more people wanting to adopt a child than there were [184] children waiting to be adopted.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: By 2019 [185], there were twice as many children waiting to be adopted in the UK than there were families waiting to adopt.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state does not get a legitimate claim to the custody of children whose parents fail to get a license.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Where parents fail to provide basic conditions for their children, this is often at least in part due to a failure on the part of the state.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many people are trapped in a cycle of poverty [186], from which escape is incredibly difficult, if at all possible. Preventing the poor from having children is punishing them for something they have no control over.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: External factors, such as social class [187] and education, are more important to a child's long-term success than bad parenting. Addressing these other issues would be a more productive way of improving children's lives.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The responsibility of providing basic conditions [188] for the child rests inherently with the parent.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If prospective parents fall pregnant, and fail to obtain a license to raise that child, they are responsible for providing the child, not the state.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are various preventative methods that are accessible to people who wish to engage in intercourse but aren't ready for parenthood.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: As they usually carry the responsibility of ensuring adequate birth control, such a license would burden women more than men.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The pill and female sterilisation are the two most common contraceptive methods in the US, and have been since 1982 [189]. This suggests the burden of ensuring a couple does not have an unintended pregnancy almost always falls on the woman.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In countries where birth control and abortions are illegal [190], due to the biological attachment women have to children, it is more likely for a woman to deal with the trauma and burden of an unlicensed child than a man.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: More women are likely to feel pressured into an abortion if they fail to get a licence, since they may perceive the trauma associated with a termination to be less than that of losing their child to the state.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Anti-abortion [191] laws and the public discussion surrounding them exemplify how restricting bodily autonomy ends up being used as a tool for oppressing women's rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Women in the US still face many obstacles [192] when trying to get contraception, which is why 20 million women in need of free birth control cannot access it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In states in the US which do not have expanded Medicaid coverage, more than two million poor adults are uninsured [193].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Given the advancement of science - through procedures such as vasalgel [194] - it is possible to significantly reduce the risk of becoming an unplanned parent. source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This is true only of countries where family planning is legal or affordable, or where citizens have easy access to healthcare institutions.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The cost of abortion can be prohibitive [195] for women in some places.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In countries where abortions are illegal, and for women who cannot afford the costs, women would likely turn to unsafe abortions [196], which can often result in maternal illness or death.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In Kenya, where abortion is only permitted in cases deemed an emergency, safe abortions offered by doctors are many times the cost [197] of 'slum clinics'.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The policy would create an impetus for states to provide safe and accessible birth control and abortion for their citizens.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many countries still limit free and open access to contraceptives through barriers like requiring people to have a prescription [201].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state often fails to provide parents with the infrastructure required to be good, responsible parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state often provides public schooling opportunities.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the US, the standards of public schools vary substantially [211], and so cannot be said to be a uniformly adequate provision of services.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many countries have high quality [212] public school systems.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Tax credits [213] based on the number of children a parent has helps to provide them with financial relief.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Inadequate welfare policy means that poor parents never have enough money to pay for their children's needs.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.text_raw: Child benefits help parents meet [218] the cost of clothes, food and school supplies.

source_retrieval.text_raw: In the US, parents' rights in relation to a child being removed from their home includes the right to challenge any decision by the courts to to do so (p. 2 [229]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In Canada, if parents don't accept the gender identity [230] chosen by their children, the state can choose to take them away from their parents.

source_retrieval.text_raw: In most US states, for example [231], rapists are denied parental rights for children conceived during the attack.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A license is only able to screen people beforehand, not act as an intervention agent after a person has a license. Rather than preventing abuse, it simply prevents able prospective parents from procreating.

source_retrieval.text_raw: It would be easy for an individual to 'tick boxes' to pass a parenting license assessment, and still go on to abuse their children at a later point.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Under the status quo, abuse or neglect of infants or very young children often goes undetected.

source_retrieval.text_raw: According to one study, up to 85% of child abuse goes undetected [232] in England.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It would be possible to introduce other early methods of detection of abuse for infants and young children. A licensing system is not needed to protect children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some countries mandate health check-ins [233] with a public nurse at different stages of a child's development.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Teachers [234] can be taught how to recognise signs of abuse.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Interventive action is currently often triggered only after some harm has already come to a child. A parenting license acts preemptively.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Most methods of detecting abuse rely on human perception, which is often flawed [235]. A licensing test would be based on expert analysis.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: For a variety of reasons, children often remain quiet about abuse.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting licenses violate parents' rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting licenses may come into conflict with many religious beliefs, which could constitute an attack on their freedom of thought, belief or religion [241].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The Catholic Church [242] believes that artificial contraception is sinful and immoral since it interferes with a divine plan to bring a new life into the world. source_retrieval.text_raw: Under some of the world's largest religions, procreation is seen as a God-given right and, for some, a duty.

source_retrieval.text_raw: State policy should prioritise what best benefits children and society at large over religious beliefs.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the Old Testament, the first command (for Christians) and the first mitzvah [243] (for Jews) given to people by God is to procreate; that they "be fruitful and multiply [244]".

source_retrieval.text_raw: In Hinduism, it is important to have a child, as it helps to fulfill one's obligations [246] to their ancestors.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are a number of religious practices that have been outlawed, even though they have had a large following because they infringed on the rights of others.

source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to procreate is an essential liberty that falls under reproductive rights and is internationally recognized. Denying someone the right to procreate through the implementation of a parenting license runs contrary to this.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Some people are legally prohibited from raising a child, showing that the right is not absolute.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is only in certain extreme circumstances that the state can infringe on parental rights. A parenting license would likely have a lower bar than most of the current situations where this is allowed.

source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to raise a child is not the same as the right to procreate.

source_retrieval.text_raw: International human rights law recognizes reproductive rights which underlie the right to procreate.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: According to the European Convention of Human Rights, the right of children to have a family exists, while the right of adults wanting children to adopt does not (pp. 9, 13 [251]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Reproductive rights [252], according to World Health Organization, rest on the recognition of the basic right of all couples and individuals to decide freely and responsibly the number, spacing and timing of their children. source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The law of the United Nations recognizes such rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Article 7.2 of the Cairo Programme of Action defines reproductive health and was adopted by 184 UN member states. source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Both Article 16 of The Universal Declaration of Human Rights [254] and Article 23 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights [255] recognize that men and women have the right to marry and to found a family without any limitation.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR [256]) is a legally binding treaty.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights [257] is not legally binding.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Article 9 of the UN Convention of the Rights of the Child [258] enables the state to separate children from their parents if the children are being mistreated or neglected.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Article 19 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child [259] requires the State to take all appropriate measures to protect children from "all forms of physical or mental violence, injury or abuse, neglect or negligent treatment, maltreatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse".

source_retrieval.text_raw: Article 20 of the Convention on the Rights of the Child [260] allows for a child to be temporarily or permanently removed from their parents if it is in the best interest of the child not to remain in the family environment.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Article 20 of the Convention of the Rights of the Child [261] recognises that such children may be placed in "foster placement, kafalah of Islamic law, adoption or if necessary placement in suitable institutions for the care of children".

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The Convention on the Rights of the Child [262] applies reactively to the protection of children. The text does not support imposing limitations on who may be parents prior to the birth of their children.

source_retrieval.text_raw: The US Supreme Court has interpreted the Constitution in favour of a right to procreate.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Imposing a license policy on everyone still maintains equal rights of procreation for single parents as well as couples. This policy will just mean a reduced right to have a child for everyone, but still an equal right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting licenses assess parents' competency prospectively. This violates the right to the presumption of innocence [269].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state is not capable of reading the future, so creating policies that act as if they do is unfair.

source_retrieval.text_raw: While the state is incapable of reading the future, it can use statistics to assess risks and attempt to minimize them. That is why policies such as requiring a driver's license exist.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Rights are not absolute and in some cases end up competing against each other.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state should not interfere in the most personal decisions that an individual makes in the course of their lives.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some people strongly believe that having children is an essential part of the human experience. This policy ensures that some people, in their own eyes, aren't able to fulfill one of their purposes as a human being.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: When parents are unable to recognize the child as a separate individual, they attempt to live through them and may become dependent on them. This can inflict serious emotional damage on the child (p. 51 [271]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The feeling of fulfillment associated with having children (and the impulse to do so) has likely played a large role in the continuation of humanity as a species over the course of history.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A licensing system may contravene privacy laws.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Competent adults are entitled to waive their privacy rights when they desire (p. 19 [272]). The desire of one to become a parent, and acquire a parenting license, would be a time when most would likely choose to waive such a right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A licensing system could be designed in a privacy sensitive manner, in line with the key privacy principles [273].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Any background checks, undertaken without permission, could violate a person's right to privacy.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Poorly raised children can impact others in society, and so states should take a proactive role in safeguarding society as a whole.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Where they clash, children's rights should overrule parents' rights.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Doctors can seek a court order to override the parents' wishes if it is in the child's best interests [276] to do so.

source_retrieval.text_raw: A parenting license system will lead to better childcare and parenting.

source_retrieval.text_raw: A parenting license would encourage responsible family planning.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo

source_retrieval.text_raw: There are various ways to offset [288] the costs of adoption, including local government subsidies, adoption tax credits (in the US), loans, and crowdfunding. Similar avenues could be explored to cover the expense of parental licenses.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Adults ought to be reasonably aware of the monetary and opportunity costs associated with raising a child, as this information is easily available.
