source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting licenses can only guarantee short term, superficial changes in a person's lifestyle or parenting choices. This is not enough to guarantee better parenting or to ensure meaningful long-term change in a child's well-being.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: As long as parents love their children, they will want to improve as parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parents are driven by metrics such as their child's happiness [322] and success [323]. The maintenance of these metrics provides an incentive to keep providing the child with what they deem is best for them.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parents [324] who are overly focused on their children's success can often be too controlling, which may stifle the child's ability to deal with obstacles in life or make independent choices as adults.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The standards set by a parenting license would provide parents with clear, tangible, and achievable requirements for good parenting.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A parenting license could help teach parents what to look out for in terms of assessing key metrics such as a child's happiness [325].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Any parent who loves their child will try their hardest to ensure that their child lives a happy [326] and fulfilling life; it is unlikely that they will become complacent if they see their child suffering or struggling.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Not all parents [327] act with love toward their offspring.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If parents would improve their skills anyway, then there is no need to implement a licensing system in the first place.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Although there is no guarantee that everyone acquiring a parenting license will be a better parent than if they hadn't, the desire to acquire the license will encourage prospective parents to learn, therefore encouraging self-improvement in those who wish to procreate.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: As everyone who wanted to be a parent would need to meet the standards of being a good parent as determined by the state, these standards would become established as normative standards as well.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: At the very least, focusing attention on a licensing system is likely to increase the belief that parenting is a skill and not an inherent ability. It is difficult to argue that increasing the amount of conversation and shared ideas would be detrimental to parenting.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This presumes ill-intent on the part of all parents that are not good parents. "Bad" parents may not be so deliberately, but may simply lack the knowledge to be a competent parent. The process of licensing could give them parenting tools that would have been otherwise unavailable.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is evidence from examining occupational licensing that increased licensing does not necessarily lead to higher quality.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A study found that occupational licensing of dentists did not lead to improved measured dental outcomes of patients (p. 176 [328]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parenting licenses will bring undue harm to people.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The emotional harm faced by parents is outweighed by the fact that the test is likely to preserve and protect the rights of children born to unfit parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Parents' stress levels can affect [329] a child’s risk of mood disorders, addiction, and even neurological disorders such as ADHD and autism. Making parents constantly think about their child being taken away from them is likely to negatively affect the child.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If a person has unexpectedly become pregnant, they will need to acquire the license while experiencing a difficult pregnancy. The need to acquire a license during an unplanned pregnancy could lead to additional stress, which could lead to a low-birthweight baby [330].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is not clear whether such a policy would be required just once, of for each subesequent child in a family. In the case where parents are worried about being granted a license for an additional child, their elevated stress levels are likely to also have an effect on any children they already have.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Currently, many children die of abuse while their case is being investigated [331] by child protection services. A licensing system can ensure that children are not brought into abusive homes in the first place.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Due to the administrative processes and systems around them, current child protection services are often inadequate and can lead to trauma for the children and parents involved.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the UK, MPs have warned [332] that child protection services are inadequate, and are 'too slow' to improve, calling out government ministers for complacency in the matter.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In many parts of the US, factors such as confidentiality laws - which hamper adequate sharing of data on abuse fatalities - and understaffing allow child protection services to operate with impunity [333].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Even where child protection services are aware of at-risk children in the US, authorities can be slow to hire staff to work the cases, despite there being a backlog [334] of open abuse and neglect investigations.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In order to cope with the unresolved grief [335] of having a child taken away, many end up relying [336] on alcohol and drugs to ease the pain.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Administrative processes can easily be amended through the introduction of different regulations and processes.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: More social workers could be hired to combat backlogs. This could be done by hiring recent graduates [337].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Any laws which make adoption more difficult can be removed through the legislative process.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Amending administrative processes may be difficult, as they could cost the state time and money.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is no will to amend the administrative processes around child protective services, as the main benefit would be to largely disenfranchised [338] parents and children, who have little political capital [339].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The primary responsibility of the state should be towards seeking to do what is best for the child, as it is vulnerable and requires protection from potentially bad parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children whose parents are deemed unfit will end up in the foster care system, which is problematic in most countries.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The foster care system would improve in a world where parenting licenses were required.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: With greater emphasis put on the foster care system, programs like CHAMPS [340], which aim to spur policy reforms to prioritise quality foster parenting and ensure that foster parents are better trained and supported, become more likely to be implemented.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Foster parents and foster care home staff would likely be required to have a parenting license.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The foster care system throughout the USA is already overcrowded, with over 400,000 children [341] in the system on any given day. It would be difficult to improve such a system in a world where more children come into the system.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The privatization [342] of foster care could be implemented to try and improve the system, but it would ultimately lead to negative outcomes.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Private investment in the foster care system could help fund training and payment [343] for prospective foster parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The foster care system in most countries is subject to exploitation and inefficiencies.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Due to a lack of adequate mental health service provision in the system, young children in foster care can often be over-prescribed psychotropic drugs [344] to modify their behavior, rather than equiping them with strategies to cope with any past trauma.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A study conducted on children from 2 to 14 in the US foster care system showed that nearly 50% [345] have significant clinical mental health problems.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The turnover of case workers [346] in the US is over 20% due to burn out, with many states allocating them three or four times the recommended case number. This undermines the efficiency of the system.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some US foster care agencies and their contractors were found to be targeting disabled children or those whose parents have died in order to exploit [347] their access to federal disability and survivor benefits, then subsequently applying for control over the child’s assets.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Non-profit organizations [348] help to account for the inefficiencies in the foster care system.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Canada is reforming [349] its indigenous foster care system.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This reform of the indigenous foster care system is only happening in the wake of revelations about how poorly [350] the Canadian government has treated indigenous children in the past.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The instability and subsequent negative effects born out of time spent in foster care are long-lasting and can shape the course of a person's life.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Swedish [351] men who were placed in foster care as children were shown to be 23% more likely to be convicted of a crime as adults than their peers.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Foster children move multiple houses when they are in the system, sometimes moving house eight or more times [352].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children in foster care move schools at least once or twice a year [353], losing out on four to six months of academic progress each time they move. This, in turn, reduces the likelihood that they will graduate.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Foster children can be moved between homes respectfully, which would diminish the harms the children would otherwise experience (p. 2 [354]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Moving foster children between homes is preferable to leaving them in unsafe environments.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children who move foster homes frequently lack stability [355] in their lives and may struggle to form relationships or bonds with anyone for a significant period of time.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children who are fostered are at higher risk [356] of becoming incarcerated, homeless, or pregnant later in life than other children, whilst also being less likely to have a job or go to college. This is often put down to state, financial, and emotional support abruptly ceasing once they reach the age of 18.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are fewer negative effects from foster care when children are placed in kinship care with extended family members.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is evidence that children in kinship care see greater outcomes than children faced in regular foster care in terms of identity formation, stability, and in gaining support through mental health challenges (p. 2 [357]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In Ireland, only 26% of foster children are in kinship [358], or relative, foster care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children who have been through the foster care system often come out as more resilient individuals.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are many examples of programs which successfully help foster children to become resilient (p. 1171 [359]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Some people who were fostered as children believe the experience made them stronger [360].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This effect could easily be in spite of having being in foster care, rather than because of it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The foster care system is not a safe or positive environment for children to be in.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: While the foster care system may not be perfect, it is a place of safety necessary for many children who need to be removed from dangerous situations.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: 40 percent [361] of foster care placements occur because the parents were substance abusers. Such parents never provided a healthy environment for their children to begin with.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A significant portion of the children who end up in foster care are confirmed victims of abuse (p. 15 [362]). They have already suffered the trauma before reaching the foster care system.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Abuse and neglect are endemic in many countries' foster care [363] and group homes [364].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Between 2009 and 2012 in the UK [365], there were between 450-550 proven cases of abuse each year for children spending time in foster care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Despite $22 billion being spent on foster care programs [366] every year in the US, nearly 60,000 children are reported weekly as abused or neglected. This suggests that the state is incapable of effectively preventing child abuse within the foster care system.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children in group homes [367] are more than 10 times as likely to be physically abused, and more than 28 times as likely to be sexually abused, than children in the general population. Both of these factors contribute [368] to conflicts with authority later in life.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The majority [369] of children in foster homes do not experience abuse, neglect or other maltreatment.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state often acts prematurely or unjustly in taking children away from their parents, which could lead to more harm for both parent and child.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If this happens when the child is young, such a separation is occuring in the most important stages [370] in the baby's development.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 2014 [371], a South Carolina woman was arrested and her child was taken away by the state for letting her 9-year-old play alone in a park.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state is justified in acting quickly if a young and vulnerable child is potentially at risk and needs to be removed from their family, since it is best to do so when they are an infant.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Separation anxiety [372] typically hits babies after 8 months, after which it becomes hard for them to remain separate from their parents. It is best to take them away when they are newborns, to prevent a relationship from forming which can lead to separation anxiety.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Trauma in a child's early years can be the cause of lifelong [373] complications for an individual: removing a child at an early age goes some way to mitigating this risk.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: When a child is removed when they are older, the circumstances of their removal from their parents can be explained to them and so it may be easier for them to understand.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Taking a child away from its mother at a young age could deprive it of its opportunity to breastfeed.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children have a right to breastfeed (p. 1 [374]).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Breastfeeding is important for the health [375] of a developing child.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Breastfeeding should be balanced [376] against the other emotional and physical needs of a child.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A child's need to be breastfed is outweighed by their need for a secure, safe, and strong bond with an attachment figure, which may be lacking in circumstances where a child is removed from their birth parents. Such a bond can be achieved as successfully [377] through bottle feeding by a caregiver.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is possible to induce lactation [378] in adoptive and foster mothers.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: 90% [379] of a child's brain development occurs in the first five years of their life. It is therefore critical that they are properly cared for in this time.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Providing special protection to those who are weak, have difficulties defending themselves, and are vulnerable [380] to violations of their fundamental human rights is a responsibility of the state.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A parenting license system would adversely affect some groups in society more than others.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Such a law could be abused as it inherently targets the bodies of people who have the ability to birth children. As such, it significantly affects women more than men.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Society already considers societal surveillance of female bodies legitimate when it comes to sexuality and pregnancy [381]. The introduction of parental licenses would exacerbate [382] this.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If raising children requires social resources beyond that which the mother can provide on her own, then it is fair to demand basic maternal competence in return for access to those resources.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In countries where they have been used, policies restricting birth have had a severe impact on the female population in particular.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In Uzbekistan [383], women are increasingly sterilised after their second child without knowledge or consent, in order to curb population growth.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In China, where a form of parenting license existed in the one-child policy, suicide rates [384] were higher for women than for men - the only country in the world where this was the case.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Countries where policies like this have been tried in the past have been authoritarian [385], and so do not serve as good examples of how a licensing policy would play out in most of the world.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Men would also be affected significantly, as they too would lose the opportunity to parent.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Women tend to form attachments with their child when they are still in the womb [386]. Men, on the other hand, tend to form attachments after spending time [387] with their baby. If a child is taken from the parent immediately after birth on account of not having a license, then the woman's lost opportunity to parent is more significant.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Where both people lose the chance to become parents, there is no unequal treatment.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: All policies adversely affect one group over another. Otherwise there would be no point to having the policy at all.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Both the licensing body as an organisation and its individual members are likely to exhibit biases when issuing licenses.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are multiple reports [388] of individual social workers exhibiting bias towards certain families. It is likely this would be transferred to a licensing policy with a similar assessment process.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Having the input of experts into the licensing tests can help ensure that the tests are fair and unbiased.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Experts [389] themselves can also be biased.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Experts have a deeper understanding [390] of a subject than most ordinary individuals. The same is true of parenting.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Experts still disagree on how best to parent children, such as how much technology [391] is optimal.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The opinions, and therefore biases, of multiple people will cancel out one another, resulting in a balanced test.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The existence of established prejudices means that licenses have the potential to discriminate against people from poorer economic backgrounds, rather than support them.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Current policies on adoption already discriminate against poor people.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children in the more deprived areas of the UK are 10 times [392] more likely to end up in foster care, compared to the rest of the country.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Failing to provide their basic necessities of life can result in severe negative impacts [393] on a child. Instituting a minimum income threshold results in fewer children suffering.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Licensing could benefit people from poorer backgrounds if the license allows qualified, but poor, parents greater access to benefits.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Offering a tax credit incentive to parents to take such a course/license could be a better solution.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is very likely that corruption would affect this license. Those with money would bribe officials to obtain licenses.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Researchers have found that there is no clear-cut causal link between poverty and parenting (p. 2 [394]). As such, there is no reason why a test for parenting would have to stipulate that the prospective parent must fall within a specific economic bracket.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In instances where individuals are not able to provide for their family, they rely on welfare from the state. There is no reason why they could not do the same, even if licenses were created.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: History shows that allowing an institution to dictate the standards by which parenting is judged opens up the possibility for such laws to be used to discriminate on the basis of race and ethnicity.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is a high correlation [395] between race and domestic violence. A racist regime could use correlations to create the illusion of causation and justify racial exclusions on that basis.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This is likely to lead to the homogenisation of society, as only those that fit a specific profile will be able to reproduce.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Studies [396] show that diversity, rather than homogeneity, is optimal for driving innovation [397]. As such, societal homogenisation is not desirable.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A homogeneous gene pool is more vulnerable [398] to potential super bugs or other environmental pressures. By creating homogeneity we endanger the entire species.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In places such as the UK and US, institutions that would be involved in determining standards of good parenting, such as medical institutions [399], psychological professionals [400] and the civil service [401], are notoriously white-dominated. As such, parental licenses would grant additional power to society at large to control and regulate the behaviour of ethnic minorities.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The prohibition of parenting for groups who engage in regressive practices is legitimate.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If a culture dictates things such as female genital mutilation [402], a country has a right to ban such practices.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A country can ban regressive practices without instituting a parenting licensing system.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are many historical examples of discrimination on the part of institutions empowered to make decisions about parenting.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Social media means governments are now more accountable [403] than ever, which shows that repeats of the issues of the past are not a certainty.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, indigenous Native Americans were dubbed unfit to parent (p. 4 [404]), and the government was able to remove their children and place them in white run boarding schools [405].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Humanity can learn [406] from history's past flaws without necessarily being bound by them.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Those who do not fit the accepted norm of a family unit could be prejudiced by this system.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Licensing could discriminate against same-sex couples.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is no legislation forbidding same sex-couples from adopting [407] in the US. There is no reason why there should be for a parental license, either.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children growing up with same-sex parents are at no disadvantage [408] compared to those with heterosexual parents. The licensing body would thus have no objective justification for discriminating against same-sex couples.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 2017, Texas [409] passed a bill that allowed state-funded adoption agencies to deny adoption [410] to those belonging to certain groups - including LGBTQ+ couples - based on their own religious views.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Countries other than the US do ban or restrict gay adoption [411].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In Israel [412], LGBTQ+ couples applying to adopt are explicitly discriminated against. Such discrimination could be replicated under the parenting licensing model.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The Catholic Church [413] has long opposed same-sex parenthood. In countries where the religion has a significant standing, it is likely that the license's conditions would be prejudiced against same-sex couples.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Current proposed ammendments to US law would extended [414] anti-discrimination laws to protect prospective adoptive and foster parents who risk prejudice in this way. The same could be done in the case of parental licenses.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Licensing could discriminate against single parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Children of single parents are at a disadvantage [415]; therefore creating a policy resulting in fewer single people becoming parents would be justified.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: While the children of single parents may be more at-risk, that does not mean they cannot overcome the challenges associated with it and grow and thrive.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many countries allow single parents to adopt.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the US, a prospective parent's marital status or relationship status does not affect [416] their eligibility to adopt.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are no adoption restrictions based on the prospective parent's partner status [417] in the UK.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Application for adoptions in Australia [418] do not require the prospective parent to be in a relationship.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In Germany, single parents can only adopt under 'exceptional cases [419]'.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: While it is not prohibited, adoption agencies and birth parents often exhibit a bias [420] towards two-parent homes, leaving single parents at the bottom of the waiting list.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In Canada, single parents are 50% less likely [421] to be placed with a child.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A financial requirement would disproportionately affect single parents as they earn less than married couples.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In South Korea [422], single-parent households earn less than half the national average.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A significant portion of single mothers in the US live in poverty [423].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Welfare states provide assistance to single parents. This would still exist in a world where parenting licenses exist, allowing single parents to raise children.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Australia [424] has a welfare programme which offers payments to single parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Single parent families across the developed world are significantly more likely to live in poverty [425] than families with two parents.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 2015, in the US, traditional two-parent families earned an income that was more than three times higher [426] than for households headed by a single mother.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Widespread backlash may not arise if the minority group is not liked [429] by society at large.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Attempting to use standardised parenting tests to eradicate a group of people would be quickly noticed, in the case that few members of a minority group acquire licenses.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
